content:
There exist different accounting systems. Management accounting focuses on company internal affairs, financial accounting informes decision makers outside the company.

  • Internal Users: Company employees and management
  • External Users: investors, creditors, regulation authorities

Financial (= external) accounting serves as the bridge between the company and external parties complying with regulatory requirements and supporting credit decisions and investment analysis.
subtitle: Financial Accounting

content:
External accounting is guided by well-defined principles:

  • Objectivity: Financial data must be based on factual, verifiable evidence
  • Prudence: Avoid overestimating revenues or underestimating liabilities
  • Comparability: Apply accounting policies consistently across periods
  • Going Concern: Assume the business will continue operations
  • Materiality: Disclose all information that could influence decisions
subtitle: Key Principles of External Accounting

content:
The following are important accounting terminology.

  • Cash Outflow: Money flows out of the company  
  • Cash Inflow: Money flows into the company  
  • Expenditure: An economic value leaves the company (e.g., on credit)  
  • Receipts: An economic value enters the company (e.g., on credit)  
  • Expense: A periodized, net-income affecting expenditure  
  • Income: A periodized, net-income affecting receipt  
  • Cost: Monetary value consumed to generate output  
  • Performance: Monetary value created through operations  
  • Revenue: All income from operating activities  
  • Profit (Net Income): What remains at the end ( Revenue – Expense)
subtitle: Core Accounting Terminology
